DOCNAME: CASE OF GAUTRIN AND OTHERS v. FRANCE
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection dismissed (Article 35-1 - Exhaustion of domestic remedies);Preliminary objection dismissed (Article 35-1 - Effective domestic remedy);Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Disciplinary proceedings;Article 6-1 - Public hearing);Violation of Article 6 - Right to a fair trial (Article 6 - Disciplinary proceedings;Article 6-1 - Impartial tribunal);Pecuniary damage - claim dismissed (Article 41 - Pecuniary damage;Just satisfaction);Non-pecuniary damage - finding of violation sufficient (Article 41 - Non-pecuniary damage;Just satisfaction)
TEXT: CARDINAL . Associations called “ ORG ” , whose object is to provide emergency medical services on call to patients , have been set up in each département ; they have formed regional associations which in turn are part of a national association known as “ ORG , GPE ” . The applicants , who are medical practitioners in ORG , are all members of this organisation .

CARDINAL . A number of ORG unions and département councils of the ordre des médecins ( ORG ) lodged complaints with the professional disciplinary bodies against the members of those associations . They maintained , inter alia , that by using a flashing blue light without permission from the authorities and displaying the name “ ORG ” on their vehicles , in telephone directories and in advertising brochures , the members of the associations were contravening LAW , which prohibited advertising .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG lodged a complaint against each of the applicants with the regional council of ORG des médecins . ORG did likewise on DATE .
It was alleged that the applicants had contravened LAW by displaying the name “ ORG ” on their vehicles and prescriptions .

CARDINAL . On DATE the regional council , composed of ORG , chairman , and PERSON , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON , Dr Delamarche , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON and PERSON , members , held that there had been a breach of LAW and suspended PERSON and PERSON from practising medicine for DATE and PERSON and CARDINAL other doctors for DATE ; the remaining CARDINAL applicants received a reprimand .
CARDINAL . The applicants appealed against those decisions to the disciplinary section of ORG ordre des médecins .

CARDINAL . On DATE that section , chaired by PERSON , honorary member of the PERSON d’Etat , and composed of PERSON , PERSON , Dr GPE , PERSON , PERSON and PERSON , members , upheld the decisions of the regional council as to the finding that there had been a breach of ORG , but reduced the penalties : Dr Gautrin and PERSON were suspended from practising medicine for DATE , the doctors who had received a DATE ’s suspension were given a reprimand and those who had been reprimanded were given a warning only . The applicants were informed of the decision on DATE . They did not appeal to the ORG d’Etat .
CARDINAL . DATE provided :
“ Medicine must not be practised as if it were a trade . Doctors shall not use any form of advertising or publicity , whether direct or indirect .
No medical exhibition shall be held or demonstration performed unless their purpose is exclusively scientific or educational . ”

CARDINAL . The Code of Professional Conduct was reformed by Decree no . CARDINAL of DATE . It now provides that any doctor participating in a duty , emergency or on - call doctor scheme “ ... shall be permitted , when carrying out his task , to affix a removable badge to his vehicle bearing the words ‘ doctor on emergency NORP , but no others ... ” and that the badge must be removed “ ... as soon as his role in the emergency is over ... ” ( Article CARDINAL ) . The code also now sets out , among other things , the information which doctors are allowed to reproduce on their prescriptions and in directories available to the public ( Articles CARDINAL–CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . It is compulsory for all doctors entitled to practise their profession in GPE to belong to the ordre national des médecins . This body ensures , among other things , that the principles of morality , probity and dedication essential to the practice of medicine are upheld and that all its members fulfil their professional duties and comply with the rules laid down in LAW . It discharges this function through département councils , regional councils and ORG ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of ORG ) .

CARDINAL . NORP The regional councils exercise disciplinary jurisdiction at first instance within the ordre des médecins . Cases may be brought before them by , among others , the département councils , and ORG unions and individual registered medical practitioners within their territorial jurisdiction ( Article L. CARDINAL of LAW ) .

ORG councils may only deliberate validly if CARDINAL of their members are present . Decisions are taken on a majority vote and must be reasoned ( ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of Decree no . DATE of DATE , as amended ) .

CARDINAL . NORP The regional council of the ordre des médecins for the GPE area is made up of CARDINAL full members divided into CARDINAL chambers and of CARDINAL substitute members ; they are all elected by members of the département councils ( Articles L. CARDINAL et seq . ) . Each chamber elects a chairman from among its members ( LAW ) .
CARDINAL . ORG ordre des médecins is composed of CARDINAL members , CARDINAL of whom are directly elected by the département councils .

CARDINAL . After each election of a proportion of its members ( DATE ) ORG elects CARDINAL of its CARDINAL members to constitute a disciplinary section – chaired by a senior member of the LOC d'Etat – with jurisdiction to hear appeals ( Articles L. CARDINAL to CARDINAL and L. CARDINAL of LAW ) . Substitute members are elected in the same way as full members ( LAW no . DATE of DATE , as amended , concerning , inter alia , the functioning of the disciplinary section ) .

The disciplinary section may only deliberate validly if , in addition to its chairman , CARDINAL of its members are present . Where the number of members present is an even number , the youngest practitioner must withdraw ( DATE first paragraph , of the Decree of DATE , as amended ) .
Appeals have , in principle , suspensive effect ( Article L. CARDINAL of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . An appeal on points of law against decisions of the disciplinary section lies to the ORG d'Etat ( LAW of DATE , as amended , and LAW ) “ as provided in ordinary administrative law ” ( LAW in fine of LAW ) .
Section DATE which came into force on DATE of PERSON no . CARDINAL of DATE reforming administrative proceedings provides :

If it quashes a decision by an administrative tribunal of last instance , the ORG d'Etat may either remit the case to the same tribunal , which shall , unless the nature of the tribunal makes it impossible , be differently constituted , or remit the case to another tribunal of the same type , or determine the merits of the case itself where the interests of proper administration of justice warrant it .
Where a second appeal on points of law is brought in a case , the PERSON d'Etat shall give a final ruling on it . ”
CARDINAL . At the time the events in the instant case occurred , the PERSON d’Etat held , following its settled case - law ( extracts from its judgment of CARDINAL DATE in the case of PERSON ) :

“ ... the provisions of LAW of LAW are not applicable to disciplinary tribunals , which do not hear criminal proceedings and do not determine civil rights and obligations . Mr PERSON accordingly can not challenge the decision appealed against on the grounds that it contravened the provisions of LAW of the aforementioned LAW relating to the holding of hearings in public and the impartiality of tribunals .

... although LAW of the PERSON of DATE provides that a tribunal to which a case has been remitted by the ORG d'Etat must , unless the nature of the tribunal makes it impossible , be differently constituted from the CARDINAL that gave the original decision , the disciplinary section of the ordre des médecins was , having regard to its nature , entitled , for the purpose of hearing the case remitted to it by the PERSON d'Etat acting in its judicial capacity in a decision of CARDINAL DATE , to be constituted as it had been on DATE , when it had given its first ruling . The grounds of appeal based on an infringement of the principle of the impartiality of tribunals and on the statutory provisions previously cited must therefore fail .

CARDINAL . The following penalties may be imposed on doctors found guilty of disciplinary offences : a warning ; a reprimand ; temporary or permanent disqualification from performing some or all of the medical duties carried out for or remunerated by the ORG , départements , municipalities , public corporations or private corporations promoting the public interest , or the medical duties carried out pursuant to welfare legislation ; temporary disqualification from practising medicine ( for a maximum of DATE ) ; and striking off the register of the ordre .

The first CARDINAL penalties also entail loss of the right to be a member of a département council , a regional council or ORG for DATE ; the other penalties entail permanent loss of that right . A doctor who has been struck off can not have his name entered in another register ( Article PERSON of LAW ) .
CARDINAL . A doctor against whom proceedings are brought may exercise a right of challenge before a regional council or ORG , as laid down in Articles CARDINAL to CARDINAL of LAW ( LAW of LAW ) .
Article CARDINAL of LAW provides that a judge may be challenged :
CARDINAL . if he or his spouse has a personal interest in the dispute ;
CARDINAL . if he or his spouse is a creditor , debtor , heir presumptive or donee of CARDINAL of the parties ;
CARDINAL . if he or his spouse is a blood relative or a relative by marriage of CARDINAL of the parties or of the spouse of CARDINAL of the parties up to the fourth degree inclusive ;
CARDINAL . if there have been or are still legal proceedings pending between him or his spouse and one of the parties or the spouse of CARDINAL of the parties ;
CARDINAL . if the case has earlier come before him as a judge or arbitrator or if he has advised CARDINAL of the parties ;
CARDINAL . if the judge or his spouse is responsible for administering the property of CARDINAL of the parties ;
CARDINAL . if there is a relationship of subordination between the judge or his spouse and CARDINAL of the parties or the spouse of CARDINAL of the parties ;
CARDINAL . if it is common knowledge that friendship or enmity subsists between the judge and CARDINAL of the parties ;

A party wishing to challenge a judge will be estopped from doing so unless he makes his challenge as soon as he becomes aware that a ground exists . “ Under no circumstances ” may a challenge be made after the hearing ( LAW ) . The challenge must “ clearly set out the grounds and be accompanied by supporting evidence ” ( Article CARDINAL ) .

On receipt of a challenge , the judge concerned shall “ withdraw ” until the question has been decided ( Article CARDINAL ) . He has DATE in which to inform the court in writing whether he accedes to the request that he stand down – in which eventuality he shall be replaced immediately DATE or , if he does not propose to stand down , of the reasons for his resisting the challenge ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) ; in the latter eventuality , or if he does not reply , the challenge is “ decided as soon as possible by a court of appeal or , if made against a member of a lay tribunal , by the president of the court of appeal , from whose decision no appeal shall lie ” ( Article CARDINAL ) . If the challenge is upheld , the judge is replaced ( Article CARDINAL ) ; if it is rejected , the challenger may be ordered to pay a civil fine of CARDINAL French francs without prejudice to any claim for damages that may be made ( Article CARDINAL ) .
To prevent an estoppel arising , challenges against CARDINAL judge shall be made together unless a ground for challenge subsequently comes to light ( Article CARDINAL ) .

A challenge against all the judges of a chamber or a court of appeal is equivalent to an application for transfer of the case to another tribunal of the same type on grounds of bias ( ORG , DATE , ORG DATE , CARDINAL ) . No such application may be made in respect of the disciplinary section of ORG ordre des médecins as there is no other body of that type to whom the case can be transferred ( ORG d’Etat , CARDINAL DATE , PERSON , GPE , pp . CARDINAL–CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . DATE no . DATE of DATE , as amended , provides , inter alia :

“ Members of regional councils may be challenged for the reasons set out in Article [ L.CARDINAL - CARDINAL of the Judicature Code ] . Challenges shall be made DATE before the hearing starts . Members of the council who are related by blood or marriage up to the fourth degree inclusive to another member of the council or to the doctor ... concerned , members of regional councils who individually or as part of a group have occupational interests in common with each other or with the practitioner concerned , and any member who initiated the complaint that led to the disciplinary proceedings shall be precluded from hearing the challenge . ”
The grounds for challenge set out in LAW are the same as those set out in LAW .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL , second paragraph , and LAW paragraph , of Decree no . DATE of DATE , as amended , provided :
“ Hearings shall not be held in public and the deliberations shall remain secret . ”

While the decisions of the disciplinary bodies of the ordre des médecins contained the names of the members who were present , they were recorded in a special register to which third parties did not have access and were not published . They were notified to certain individuals and institutions only ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the decree ) .
CARDINAL . Those rules were amended by Decree no . CARDINAL of DATE .

Hearings before a body of the ordre sitting to determine disciplinary charges are now held in public . However , the chairman of the body in question may , of his own motion or on an application by CARDINAL of the parties or by the person whose complaint has led to the case being brought before a regional council , exclude the public from all or part of the hearing in the interests of public order or where respect for private life or medical confidentiality so justifies ( Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Decree of CARDINAL DATE , as amended by LAW DATE ) .

Decisions are now made public , but the bodies in question may decide not to include in the certified copies any details – such as surnames DATE which might be incompatible with respect for private life or medical confidentiality ( Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Decree of DATE , as amended by LAW DATE ) .
